titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Linda Wu and Janita Gee records of the Gee family in Houston, 1955-2011 MS 878

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-07-29 10:13:27 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: Linda Wu and Janita Gee records of the Gee family in Houston

physdesc.extent: 4 boxes (2 of plaques / memorabilia, 1 of documents, one of oversize photos and proclamations)

did.abstract: This collection includes sources which document Gee restaurants and/or events, the family of Jane and Albert Gee, and activities of the Chinese American Citizens Alliance (Houston Chapter). Formats include photos (circa 75), letters, plaques, awards, certificates, newspaper clippings, magazine clippings, brochures, pamphlets.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Gee family first rose to prominence with C.B. Albert Gee (b. 1920) and his success in the Houston restaurant business. He began working in the industry in 1936, first as an assistant to his uncle Harry Gee, Sr., before opening up restaurants of his own, such as Gee's Kitchen, the Frying Pan, and the Ding How—the latter of which was his first large restaurant. He went on to establish the PolyAsian Restaurants, where Cantonese, Japanese, and Polynesian foods were served. He helped pioneer Chinese take out with the Chinese Oven and Hong Kong Chef restaurants. He served as president of the Houston Restaurant Association from 1961-62 as well as president of the Houston Lodge of the Chinese American Citizens Alliance (CACA), which he helped to found. For the first hundred years or so of CACA's history (founded in 1895), he was the only person not from California to ever serve as the CACA National Grand President. The records in this collection—documenting Albert Gee's recognition in CACA, the Houston community, and the nation—come from his two daughters, Linda Wu and Janita Gee. Wu graduated from the University of Texas, Austin with a degree in fashion merchandising, working in retailing with Joske's of Texas before becoming a real estate broker; she eventually retired, remaining active in Houston's Asian American community and serving as CACA president in 2011. Gee graduated from Texas Christian University and got her master's from San Francisco State College before working as head of the science department at Moreau Catholic High School in Hayward, California.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: This collection includes sources which document Gee restaurants and/or events, the family of Jane and Albert Gee, and activities of the Chinese American Citizens Alliance (Houston Chapter). Formats include photos (circa 75), letters, plaques, awards, certificates, newspaper clippings, magazine clippings, brochures, pamphlets.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This material is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Linda Wu and Janita Gee records of the Gee family in Houston, 1955-2011, MS 878, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from this material should be facilitated through the Woodson Research Center.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Linda Wu and Janita Gee records of the Gee family in Houston, MS 878, Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library, Rice University

did.unittitle: Series I: Documents and photographs
Letters and correspondence
Photographs of CACA and Gee Family events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Including Albert Gee, Jane Gee, Linda Gee, Janita Gee, Hong Kong Chef (Bellaire restaurant), Hugh O'Bryan,Connie Chng, Kim sisters (Korean musical act), Gordon McRae, Jack Chow, and others unidentified.

did.unittitle: Gee family magazine and newspaper clippings
CACA programs and publications
Brochures and programs
Albert Gee biographical sketch, written 1998, and business card
Copy of Senate resolution 201 (senatorial apology for the Chinese Exclusion Act)
Series II: Awards
Awards and certificates
Plaque: Gee Family Association Hall of Fae, Albert C.B. Gee,
Gavel: Albert Gee, President 1956, CACA Houston Lodge
Gavel: Albert Gee, Outstanding Leadership, President 1956, CACA Houston Lodge, 1958-1959
Plaque: Albert Gee, Outstanding and Dedicated Service, CACA, 1967
Gavel: Jane Gee, HRS Auxilliary, 1961-1962
Lucite medal: Albert Gee for International Understanding, Houston International Trade and Travel Fair, 1960
Plaque: Jane Gee, Chairperson, Miss Chinatown Houston Pageant, 1993
Gavel on plaque: Jane Gee, Outstanding Leadership and Accomplishment, CACA Houston, 1983-1984
Series III: Oversize documents, photographs, and awards
Texas State Legislature gavel honoring House Resolution 1742 for CACA National Convention
Chinese language documents
Proclamation, Jane Eng Gee Day 2003
Resolution for Albert Gee's election as CACA President (national), by Mayor Louis Welch, 1971
Plaque: Jane Gee, first woman president of CACA Houston Lodge, 1993
